title: St. Cloud, Minnesota
text:
St. Cloud is a <a href="city">city</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> and the largest population center in the state's <a href="Central%20Minnesota">central region</a>. Its population is 68,462 according to the 2019 US census estimates, making it Minnesota's tenth largest city. St. Cloud is the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Stearns%20County%2C%20Minnesota">Stearns County</a> and was named after the city of <a href="Saint-Cloud">Saint-Cloud</a>, <a href="France">France</a> (in Île-de-France, near Paris), which was named after the 6th-century French monk <a href="Clodoald">Clodoald</a>.
Though mostly in Stearns County, St. Cloud also extends into <a href="Benton%20County%2C%20Minnesota">Benton</a> and <a href="Sherburne%20County%2C%20Minnesota">Sherburne</a> counties, and straddles the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a>. It is the center of contiguous <a href="St.%20Cloud%20metropolitan%20area">urban area</a>, with <a href="Waite%20Park%2C%20Minnesota">Waite Park</a>, <a href="Sauk%20Rapids%2C%20Minnesota">Sauk Rapids</a>, <a href="Sartell%2C%20Minnesota">Sartell</a>, <a href="St.%20Joseph%2C%20Minnesota">St. Joseph</a>, <a href="Rockville%2C%20Minnesota">Rockville</a>, and <a href="St.%20Augusta%2C%20Minnesota">St. Augusta</a> directly bordering the city, and <a href="Foley%2C%20Minnesota">Foley</a>, <a href="Rice%2C%20Minnesota">Rice</a>, <a href="Kimball%2C%20Minnesota">Kimball</a>, <a href="Clearwater%2C%20Minnesota">Clearwater</a>, <a href="Clear%20Lake%2C%20Minnesota">Clear Lake</a>, and <a href="Cold%20Spring%2C%20Minnesota">Cold Spring</a> nearby. The St. Cloud metropolitan area had a population of 202,996 at the 2020 census. It has been listed as the fifth-largest metro with a presence in Minnesota, behind <a href="Minneapolis%E2%80%93St.%20Paul">Minneapolis–St. Paul</a>, <a href="Duluth%E2%80%93Superior">Duluth–Superior</a>, <a href="Fargo-Moorhead">Fargo-Moorhead</a>, and <a href="Rochester%2C%20Minnesota">Rochester</a>. But the entire St. Cloud area is entirely in Minnesota, while most of Fargo-Moorhead's population is in North Dakota and Superior, Wisconsin, contributes significant population to the Duluth area.
St. Cloud is northwest of the Twin Cities of <a href="Minneapolis%E2%80%93St.%20Paul">Minneapolis–St. Paul</a> along <a href="Interstate%2094%20in%20Minnesota">Interstate 94</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Route%2052%20in%20Minnesota">U.S. Highway 52</a> (conjoined with I-94), <a href="U.S.%20Route%2010%20in%20Minnesota">U.S. Highway 10</a>, <a href="Minnesota%20State%20Highway%2015">Minnesota State Highway 15</a>, and <a href="Minnesota%20State%20Highway%2023">Minnesota State Highway 23</a>. The St. Cloud <a href="United%20States%20metropolitan%20area">Metropolitan Statistical Area</a> (MSA) is made up of Stearns and Benton Counties. The city was included in a newly defined Minneapolis–St. Paul–St. Cloud Combined Statistical Area (CSA) in 2000. St. Cloud as a whole has never been part of the 13-county MSA comprising <a href="Minneapolis">Minneapolis</a>, <a href="St.%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">St. Paul</a>, <a href="Bloomington%2C%20Minnesota">Bloomington</a> and parts of western <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>.
<a href="St.%20Cloud%20State%20University">St. Cloud State University</a>, Minnesota's third-largest public university, is located between the downtown area and the Beaver Islands, which form a maze for a two-mile stretch of the Mississippi. The approximately 30 undeveloped islands are a popular destination for kayak and canoe enthusiasts and are part of a state-designated 12-mile stretch of wild and scenic river.
St. Cloud owns and operates a <a href="hydroelectricity">hydroelectric</a> dam on the Mississippi that can produce up to ten <a href="watt">megawatts</a> of electricity.
History.
What is now the St. Cloud area was occupied by various indigenous peoples for thousands of years. Europeans encountered the <a href="Odawa%20people">Ottawa</a>, <a href="Ojibwe%20people">Ojibwe</a>, and <a href="Ho-Chunk">Winnebago</a> when they started to trade with Native American peoples. 
Minnesota was organized as a territory in 1849. The St. Cloud area was opened up to settlers in 1851 after treaty negotiations with the <a href="Ho%20Chunk">Winnebago</a> (Ho-Chunk) tribe in 1851 and 1852. John Wilson, a <a href="Maine">Maine</a> native with French <a href="Huguenot">Huguenot</a> ancestry and an interest in <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>, named the settlement St. Cloud after <a href="Saint-Cloud">Saint-Cloud</a>, the <a href="Paris">Paris</a> suburb where Napoleon had his favorite palace. 
St. Cloud was a waystation on the Middle and Woods branches of the <a href="Red%20River%20Trails">Red River Trails</a> used by <a href="M%C3%A9tis">Métis</a> traders between the Canada–US border at <a href="Pembina%2C%20North%20Dakota">Pembina</a>, North Dakota and <a href="Saint%20Paul%2C%20Minnesota">St. Paul</a>. The cart trains often consisted of hundreds of <a href="Red%20River%20ox%20carts">oxcarts</a>. The Métis, bringing furs to trade for supplies to take back to their rural settlements, would camp west of the city and cross the Mississippi in St. Cloud or just to the north in Sauk Rapids
The City of St. Cloud was incorporated in 1856. It developed from three distinct settlements, known as Upper Town, Middle Town, and Lower Town, that were established by European-American settlers starting in 1853. Remnants of the deep ravines that separated the three are still visible today. Middle Town was settled primarily by Catholic <a href="Germans">German</a> immigrants and migrants from eastern states, who were recruited to the region by Father <a href="Francis%20Xavier%20Pierz">Francis Xavier Pierz</a>, a Catholic priest who also ministered as a <a href="missionary">missionary</a> to Native Americans. Lower Town was founded by settlers from the <a href="Northern%20Tier%20%28United%20States%29">Northern Tier</a> of <a href="New%20England">New England</a> and the <a href="mid-Atlantic%20states">mid-Atlantic states</a>, including former residents of upstate New York. 
Upper Town, or Arcadia, was plotted by <a href="General">General</a> <a href="Sylvanus%20Lowry">Sylvanus Lowry</a>, a slaveholder and trader from <a href="Kentucky">Kentucky</a> who brought <a href="slaves">slaves</a> with him, although Minnesota was organized as a free territory. He served on the territorial Council from 1852 to 1853 and was elected St. Cloud's first mayor in 1856, serving for one year.
<a href="Jane%20Grey%20Swisshelm">Jane Grey Swisshelm</a>, an abolitionist newspaper editor who had migrated from <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, repeatedly attacked Lowry in print. At one point Lowry organized a "Committee of Vigilance" that broke into Swisshelm's newspaper office and removed her press, throwing it into the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a>. Lowry started a rival paper, "The Union".
The US Supreme Court's 1857 decision in "<a href="Dred%20Scott%20v.%20Sandford">Dred Scott</a>" ruled that slaves could not file <a href="freedom%20suits">freedom suits</a> and found the <a href="Missouri%20Compromise">Missouri Compromise</a> unconstitutional, so the territory's prohibition against slavery became unenforceable. Nearly all Southerners left the St. Cloud area when the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> broke out, taking their slaves with them. Lowry died in the city in 1865.
Beginning in 1864, <a href="Stephen%20Miller%20%28Minnesota%20governor%29">Stephen Miller</a> served a two-year term as Minnesota governor, the only citizen of St. Cloud ever to hold the office. Miller was a "<a href="Pennsylvania%20German">Pennsylvania German</a> businessman", lawyer, writer, active abolitionist, and personal friend of <a href="Alexander%20Ramsey">Alexander Ramsey</a>. He was on the state's Republican electoral ticket with Abraham Lincoln in 1860.
<a href="Steamboat">Steamboat</a>s regularly docked at St. Cloud as part of the fur trade and other commerce, although river levels were not reliable. This ended with the construction of the <a href="Coon%20Rapids%20Dam">Coon Rapids Dam</a> in 1912–14. <a href="Granite">Granite</a> quarries have operated in the area since the 1880s, giving St. Cloud its nickname, "The Granite City."
In 1917, <a href="Samuel%20Pandolfo">Samuel Pandolfo</a> started the Pan Motor Company in St. Cloud. Pandolfo claimed his Pan-Cars would make St. Cloud the new <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> but the company failed at a time when resources were directed toward the <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> effort. He was later convicted and imprisoned for attempting to defraud investors.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of ; is land and is water. The city is bisected by the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a>, and part of the <a href="Sauk%20River%20%28Minnesota%29">Sauk River</a> runs along its northern edge. Just south of downtown, near <a href="Technical%20Senior%20School">Technical High School</a>, is the 7-acre, 35-feet-deep Lake George.
Climate.
St. Cloud lies in the warm summer <a href="humid%20continental%20climate">humid continental climate</a> zone (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "Dfb"), with warm summers and cold winters with moderate to heavy snowfall. The monthly normal daily mean temperature ranges from in January to in July. The record high temperature is 107 °F (42 °C). The record low temperature is -43 °F (-42 °C).
Demographics.
2020 census.
St. Cloud is the principal city of the <a href="St.%20Cloud%2C%20Minnesota%20metropolitan%20area">St. Cloud Metropolitan Statistical Area</a>, a <a href="United%20States%20metropolitan%20area">metropolitan area</a> that covers Sherburne, Benton and Stearns counties and had a combined population of 202,996 at the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20Census">2020 census</a>, an increase of 6.67% since 2010.
2010 census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2010, there were 65,842 people, 25,439 households, and 13,348 families residing in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was . There were 27,338 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 84.6% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 7.8% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.7% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 3.7% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.8% from <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 2.5% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 2.4% of the population.
There were 25,439 households, of which 25.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 37.6% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 10.4% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.5% had a male householder with no wife present, and 47.5% were non-families. 30.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 7.8% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.95.
The median age in the city was 28.8 years. 18.9% of residents were under the age of 18; 23.9% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 25.5% were from 25 to 44; 21.5% were from 45 to 64; and 10.3% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 51.5% male and 48.5% female.
2000 census.
In the 2000 <a href="census">census</a>, 27.3% of St. Cloud households had children under the age of 18 living with them, 41.4% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 9.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 45.9% were non-families. 30.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.40 and the average family size was 3.00.
The racial makeup of the city was 91.7% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 2.4% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">African American</a>, 0.7% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 3.1% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.7% <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.4% from two or more races. <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race were 1.3% of the population.
The median income for a household in the city was $37,346, and the median income for a family was $50,460. Males had a median income of $33,670 versus $23,759 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was $19,769. About 5.0% of families and 13.1% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 7.0% of those under age 18 and 9.9% of those age 65 or over.
Top employers.
According to St. Cloud's 2020 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,

Figures reflect only full-time employees. Several businesses have a significant part-time staff. * Includes employees at sites outside of St. Cloud. ** Business has significant part-time staff in addition to the full-time employee count indicated. *** Does not include Stearns County full-time employees now working at county satellite offices outside of the City of St. Cloud.
Arts, culture and events.
In 2019 the city of <a href="Saint%20Cloud%2C%20Minnesota">Saint Cloud, Minnesota</a> was awarded three first places awards from the <a href="Rome">Rome</a> based International Awards for Liveable Communities (LivCom), one of several "<a href="most%20livable%20cities">most livable cities</a>" awards. The city won the first-place whole city award for its size and first-place for cities of all sizes for Enhancement of landscapes and public spaces, Arts, culture and heritage management and Community participation and empowerment. The international organization praised the city for its focus on improving parkland and trails, as well as its enhancements and maintenace of 96 parks. The city has been a finalist at the LivCom awards four times since 2007.
The St. Cloud Area Convention and Visitors Bureau promotes an area events calendar, dining and lodging information. The city-owned St. Cloud River's Edge Convention Center hosts a variety of events including regional conferences, consumer/trade shows, small group meetings and social events.
Sports.
The city is home to:
Parks and recreation.
The city maintains 95 parks, totaling more than and ranging in size from 80 "neighborhood and mini parks" to . The largest developed park, Whitney Memorial Park, is the former location of the city airport. It features a recreation center for senior citizens, a dog park, and numerous softball, baseball, and soccer fields.
Government.
Since 2005, St. Cloud's mayor has been <a href="Dave%20Kleis">Dave Kleis</a>. He was reelected to a fifth term in 2020.
St. Cloud has been moved by Congressional redistricting to a wide variety of Minnesota regions, including northern, south central, northwest and southwest. In Congressional district maps in effect since 2003, it has been grouped with rural areas and suburbs north and west of the Twin Cities. St. Cloud is the largest city in <a href="Minnesota%27s%206th%20congressional%20district">Minnesota's 6th congressional district</a>, represented by Republican <a href="Tom%20Emmer">Tom Emmer</a>.
The city makes up the majority of population of Minnesota State Senate District 14, which straddles the Mississippi River and includes parts of three counties, represented by <a href="Aric%20Putnam">Aric Putnam</a>. Minnesota House District 14A includes generally western parts of the city as well as <a href="Waite%20Park%2C%20Minnesota">Waite Park</a>, <a href="St.%20Augusta%2C%20Minnesota">St. Augusta</a> and adjacent rural areas, represented by <a href="Dan%20Wolgamott">Dan Wolgamott</a>. District 14B includes east central and northeast St. Cloud, neighboring <a href="Sauk%20Rapids%2C%20Minnesota">Sauk Rapids</a> and parts of rural Benton and Sherburne Counties, represented by <a href="Tama%20Theis">Tama Theis</a>.
Congressional and legislative district boundaries are subject to change with redistricting based on the 2020 census.
Past include:
St. Cloud was recognized in 2016 for its efforts to convert to clean renewable energy, converting from 5 to 80 percent renewable energy in three years, utilizing solar gardens, street light improvements, biogas and other energy efficiency initiatives.
Politics.
President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris won St. Cloud's votes in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2020 presidential election</a> by a margin of 9%, higher than the state margin of 7.12%. In <a href="2016%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2016</a>, former President Donald Trump won St. Cloud by 1.75% over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.
Education.
The city of St. Cloud is part of the St. Cloud Area School District, which serves St. Cloud, St. Augusta, Clearwater, Waite Park, St. Joseph, Haven Township, and parts of Sauk Rapids. The district has eight elementary schools, a new K-8 school in St. Joseph, and two major public high schools, St. Cloud <a href="Technical%20Senior%20School">Technical High School</a> and St. Cloud <a href="Apollo%20High%20School%20%28Minnesota%29">Apollo High School</a>. St. Cloud also has a major private high school, <a href="Cathedral%20High%20School%20%28St.%20Cloud%2C%20Minnesota%29">Cathedral High School</a>. Both public high schools offer a broad selection of Advanced Placement courses and rank high in the state in the number of AP tests taken and of test takers. St. Cloud Tech is the older of the two, opening in 1917, and is just west of downtown on the city's south side. Apollo opened in 1970 and serves the expanding north side of the city. Other high schools and secondary schools that serve the city of St. Cloud include St. Robert Bellarmine's Academy, St. Cloud Christian School, Immaculate Conception Academy, <a href="Saint%20John%27s%20Preparatory%20School%20%28Collegeville%2C%20Minnesota%29">St. John's Preparatory School</a>, St. Cloud Alternative Learning Center, and charter school STRIDE Academy, which is K-8. The nearby cities of Sauk Rapids and Sartell also have their own school districts and high schools, bringing the number of public high schools in the metropolitan area to four.
Colleges.
St. Cloud is home to several higher education institutions, including Minnesota's third-largest university, <a href="St.%20Cloud%20State%20University">St. Cloud State University</a>. St. Cloud State's fall 2020 enrollment was 12,607, in a year affected by the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
St. Cloud's other post-secondary institutions and campuses include <a href="St.%20Cloud%20Technical%20and%20Community%20College">St. Cloud Technical and Community College</a> (SCTCC) and <a href="Rasmussen%20College">Rasmussen College</a>. Neighboring <a href="Sartell">Sartell</a> is home to a campus of the <a href="Duluth%2C%20Minnesota">Duluth</a>-based <a href="College%20of%20St.%20Scholastica">College of St. Scholastica</a>, and the <a href="College%20of%20St.%20Benedict">College of St. Benedict and St. John's University</a> are in neighboring St. Joseph and nearby Collegeville, respectively.
Media.
The main <a href="newspaper">newspaper</a> is the "<a href="St.%20Cloud%20Times">St. Cloud Times</a>", a <a href="Gannett%20Company">Gannett</a> daily newspaper.
St. Cloud is part of the Twin Cities television market. One full-power station, the <a href="Ion%20Television">Ion</a>-owned <a href="KPXM-TV">KPXM-TV</a> (channel 41), is licensed to the city, but moved its transmitter to the Twin Cities in 2009 as part of the digital transition, and maintains no presence in the city. <a href="WCMN-LP">WCMN-LP</a> (channel 13) is a <a href="low-power%20broadcasting%23Television">low-power</a> station licensed to St. Cloud that broadcasts in <a href="ATSC%203.0">ATSC 3.0</a>. Additionally, <a href="St.%20Cloud%20State%20University">St. Cloud State University</a> students operate cable-only UTVS (channel 180), which includes local news and broadcasts from a studio on campus.
<a href="Radio">Radio</a> stations include:
Infrastructure.
Transportation.
St. Cloud is a regional transportation hub within Minnesota. Major roadways including <a href="Interstate%2094">Interstate Highway 94</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Route%2010">U.S. Highway 10</a>, and Minnesota State Highways <a href="Minnesota%20State%20Highway%2015">15</a> and <a href="Minnesota%20State%20Highway%2023">23</a> pass through the city.
<a href="Bus">Bus</a> service within the city and to neighboring <a href="Sartell%2C%20Minnesota">Sartell</a>, <a href="Sauk%20Rapids%2C%20Minnesota">Sauk Rapids</a>, and <a href="Waite%20Park%2C%20Minnesota">Waite Park</a> is offered through <a href="St.%20Cloud%20Metropolitan%20Transit%20Commission">St. Cloud Metro Bus</a>, which was recognized in 2007 as the best transit system of its size in North America. An innovative system gives transit buses a slight advantage at stoplights in order to improve efficiency and on-time performance. The <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20120131123511/http%3A//stcloudmtc.com/transit_center.php">Metro Bus Transit Center</a> in the downtown area is also shared with <a href="Jefferson%20Lines">Jefferson Lines</a>, providing national bus service.
Bus service links downtown St. Cloud and St. Cloud State University with the western terminus of the <a href="Northstar%20Line">Northstar Commuter Rail</a> line in <a href="Big%20Lake%20%28Metro%20Transit%20station%29">Big Lake</a>, by the way of Northstar Link Commuter Bus, which in turn links to the <a href="Metro%20Transit%20%28Minnesota%29">Metro Transit</a> bus and light rail system at <a href="Target%20Field%20%28Metro%20Transit%20station%29">Target Field Station</a> in downtown <a href="Minneapolis">Minneapolis</a>.
Several rail lines run through the city, which is <a href="St.%20Cloud%20%28Amtrak%20station%29">a stop</a> on <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>'s "<a href="Empire%20Builder">Empire Builder</a>" passenger rail line.
St. Cloud is also home to <a href="St.%20Cloud%20Regional%20Airport">St. Cloud Regional Airport</a>, from which daily connecting flights to <a href="Minneapolis%E2%80%93Saint%20Paul%20International%20Airport">Minneapolis–Saint Paul International Airport</a> were made on <a href="Delta%20Connection">Delta Connection</a>, operated by <a href="Mesaba%20Airlines">Mesaba Airlines</a>, until January 1, 2010, when the service was discontinued. On December 15, 2012, Allegiant Air began nonstop flights between St. Cloud Regional Airport and Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport, on McDonnell Douglas MD-80 aircraft.
